title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #446**

Let δ(n) = density of integers with a divisor in (n, 2n).

**Part 1:** δ(n) ≍ 1/((log n)^α (log log n)^{3/2}) where α ≈ 0.08607

**Part 2:** Is δ₁(n) = o(δ(n))? NO - Ford disproved this in 2008.

**Status:** SOLVED (Ford 2008)
mathContext: A 74-year problem from Besicovitch (1934) to Ford (2008), resolved through deep analytic number theory.

title: Divisor in Interval
content:
**hasDivisorInInterval m n:**

The integer m has a divisor d in the open interval (n, 2n).

**Definition:** ∃ d : ℕ, n < d ∧ d < 2n ∧ d | m

This is the central predicate for the problem.
mathContext: The interval (n, 2n) contains exactly n-1 integers: n+1, n+2, ..., 2n-1.

title: Density Function δ(n)
content:
**delta n:**

The asymptotic density of integers divisible by some d ∈ (n, 2n).

δ(n) = lim_{N→∞} |{m ≤ N : ∃d ∈ (n, 2n), d | m}| / N

This limit exists by standard density arguments.
mathContext: Asymptotic density measures how common a property is among all integers.

title: Divisor Count
content:
**divisorCount m n:**

The number of divisors of m in the interval (n, 2n).

**Definition:** Filter divisors d with n < d < 2n and count.

This is used to define δᵣ(n) - density with exactly r such divisors.
mathContext: Counting divisors in intervals is fundamental to the Erdős-Ford theory.

title: Density δᵣ(n)
content:
**deltaR n r:**

The density of integers with exactly r divisors in (n, 2n).

δᵣ(n) = lim_{N→∞} |{m ≤ N : divisorCount(m, n) = r}| / N

Erdős asked if δ₁(n) = o(δ(n)). Ford showed this is FALSE.
mathContext: The decomposition δ(n) = Σᵣ δᵣ(n) gives insight into divisor distribution.

title: The Constant α
content:
**alpha:**

α = 1 - (1 + log log 2) / log 2 ≈ 0.08607

This constant appears in the asymptotic δ(n) ≍ 1/(log n)^α.

It's defined explicitly using nested logarithms.
mathContext: The appearance of log log 2 reflects deep structure in divisor distribution. This constant also appears in related problems.

title: Numerical Value of α
content:
**alpha_value:**

0.086 < α < 0.087

The constant α ≈ 0.08607 is small but positive, meaning δ(n) decays slowly (like 1/(log n)^{0.086}).
mathContext: The small exponent explains why δ(n) → 0 so slowly.

title: Besicovitch (1934)
content:
**besicovitch_1934:**

liminf δ(n) = 0

The density can get arbitrarily small along subsequences. This was the first result on this problem.

Published in Math. Annalen.
mathContext: Besicovitch's result showed δ(n) is not bounded away from 0, initiating the study.

title: Erdős (1935)
content:
**erdos_1935:**

δ(n) = o(1)

The density tends to 0 as n → ∞. This strengthens Besicovitch from liminf to full limit.

Published in J. London Math. Soc.
mathContext: Erdős was 22 when he proved this, establishing the basic decay of δ(n).

title: Erdős (1960)
content:
**erdos_1960:**

δ(n) = (log n)^{-α + o(1)}

First quantitative bound with the correct exponent α. The error term o(1) was later refined to the log-log factor.

Published in Russian (Vestnik Leningrad. Univ.).
mathContext: This result pinned down the correct power of log n, leaving only the secondary terms.

title: Ford's Asymptotic (2008)
content:
**ford_2008_main:**

δ(n) ≍ 1 / ((log n)^α (log log n)^{3/2})

The exact growth rate, up to multiplicative constants:
∃ c, C > 0 such that c·f(n) ≤ δ(n) ≤ C·f(n)
where f(n) = 1/((log n)^α (log log n)^{3/2})

Published in Ann. of Math.
mathContext: Ford's 2008 paper in the Annals of Mathematics completely resolved the first question.

title: Ford's Disproof (2008)
content:
**ford_2008_disproof:**

δ₁(n) is NOT o(δ(n))!

Erdős conjectured that integers with exactly one divisor in (n, 2n) are negligible. Ford proved this is FALSE:

∃ c > 0: δ₁(n) ≥ c · δ(n) for all large n.
mathContext: This disproof shows the divisor count is concentrated, not spread out.

title: Ford's Generalization
content:
**ford_2008_general:**

For each r ≥ 1: δᵣ(n) ≫ᵣ δ(n)

Integers with exactly r divisors in (n, 2n) have density comparable to the total density.

The implicit constant depends on r.
mathContext: This generalizes the disproof: no single divisor count dominates.

title: Erdős's Doubt (1986)
content:
**erdos_doubt_1986:**

At Oberwolfach in 1986, Erdős said he was "quite sure" that δ₁(n) = o(δ(n)), but noted that "recent results of Tenenbaum throw some doubt on this."

His intuition to doubt was correct - Ford disproved it 22 years later.
mathContext: Erdős's self-doubt shows the depth of his mathematical intuition.

title: Tenenbaum (1984)
content:
**tenenbaum_1984:**

Refined Erdős's 1960 estimates, providing more precise bounds that hinted at the eventual disproof.

Published in Compositio Math.
mathContext: Tenenbaum's work was the "recent results" that gave Erdős doubt.

title: Primes Have No Divisor
content:
**prime_no_divisor:**

If p > 2n is prime, then p has no divisors in (n, 2n).

**Proof:** The only divisors of prime p are 1 and p. Since n < d < 2n < p, neither 1 nor p is in the interval.
mathContext: This shows primes larger than 2n are not counted in δ(n).

title: Problem Summary
content:
**erdos_446_summary:**

Combines all main results:

**Part 1:** δ(n) ≍ 1/((log n)^α (log log n)^{3/2})
where α ≈ 0.08607

**Part 2:** δ₁(n) ≥ c · δ(n) (NOT o(δ(n)))

**Timeline:**
1934: Besicovitch (liminf = 0)
1935: Erdős (o(1))
1960: Erdős (correct exponent)
1984: Tenenbaum (refinement)
2008: Ford (complete resolution)
mathContext: This theorem bundles the 74-year resolution of Problem #446.

title: Problem Resolved
content:
**erdos_446_solved:**

Erdős Problem #446 was completely resolved by Kevin Ford in 2008.

Both the growth rate question and the secondary conjecture were answered.
mathContext: Ford's 2008 Annals paper is a landmark in analytic number theory.
